  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath3 be the automorphism group of a free group @xmath1 on @xmath4 generators @xmath5 .",
    "a reduced word @xmath6 is called a _ palindrome _ if it is equal to its reverse @xmath7 . in @xcite collins",
    "defines the _ palidromic automorphism group _ @xmath0 as the subgroup of @xmath3 consisting of all automorphisms @xmath8 for which @xmath9 is a palindrome for all @xmath10 .",
    "he showed that the group was generated by three types of automorphisms :    * maps @xmath11 , @xmath12 , which send @xmath13 and fix all other generators @xmath14 .",
    "* maps @xmath15 which send @xmath16 and fix all other generators @xmath14 .",
    "* maps corresponding to elements of the symmetric group @xmath17 which permute the @xmath18 among themselves .",
    "the portion of @xmath0 generated by just the @xmath11 is called the _ elementary palindromic automorphism group _ of @xmath1 and denoted @xmath19 .",
    "note that @xmath20 collins showed that a set of defining relators for @xmath19 is given by relations of the form    1 .",
    "@xmath21 2 .",
    "@xmath22 3 .",
    "@xmath23    he remarked how similar this was to the relations for the pure symmetric automorphism group @xmath24 ( see gilbert s work in @xcite ) :    1 .",
    "@xmath25 2 .",
    "@xmath26 3 .   @xmath27    where @xmath28 , @xmath12 , sends @xmath29 and fixes all other generators @xmath14 .",
    "on the basis of this , collins conjectured that one could find the virtual cohomological dimension of @xmath0 by employing the methods of @xcite , as he did for @xmath30 in @xcite .",
    "he also speculated that @xmath19 is torsion free , just as @xmath24 is .",
    "we are able to answer both of these questions in this paper , as well as obtaining several interesting facts about the cohomology of @xmath0 .",
    "[ c34 ] let @xmath0 be the palindromic automorphism group of the free group @xmath1 on @xmath4 letters and let @xmath19 be the subgroup of elementary palindromic automorphisms .",
    "then * a ) * the virtual cohomological dimension of @xmath0 is @xmath31 . *",
    "b ) * ( i ) for the prime 2 , the krull dimension of @xmath32 is @xmath4 . for odd primes @xmath33 ,",
    "the krull dimension of @xmath34 is @xmath35 $ ] .",
    "( ii ) in the range where the krull dimension of @xmath34 is 1 , the period is @xmath36 .",
    "* c ) * the group @xmath19 is torsion free . * d ) * the cohomology group @xmath37 .",
    "* e ) * if @xmath33 is an odd prime and @xmath38 , then the farrell cohomology of the palindromic automorphism group is the same as that of the symmetric group on @xmath33 elements : @xmath39    for analogous results concerning @xmath3 , see @xcite and @xcite .",
    "see @xcite for the definition of the farrell cohomology @xmath40 of a group @xmath41 of finite vcd with coefficients in a @xmath41-module @xmath42 and also see @xcite for several useful properties of these cohomology groups .",
    "the remainder of this paper is structured as follows . in section 2",
    ", we discuss @xmath0 and note how it relates to some other groups , while in section 3 we introduce the space @xmath43 which @xmath0 acts on and prove parts a ) and d ) of theorem [ c34 ] .",
    "section 4 is concerned with a realization proposition which allows us to establish parts b ) ( i ) and c ) of the main theorem . finally , section 5 looks in more detail at the cohomology of @xmath0 at odd primes @xmath33 and establishes parts b ) ( ii ) and e ) of the main theorem .",
    "the authors would like to thank john meier for an enlightening conversation about symmetric automorphisms of free groups , aiding the presentation of this paper .",
    "let @xmath44 be the spine of auter space ( see @xcite,@xcite,@xcite ) and @xmath45 .",
    "let @xmath46 be the automorphism which sends @xmath16 for each @xmath10 .",
    "define the @xmath47-graph @xmath48 to be a graph with 2 vertices and @xmath49 edges , where each edge goes from one vertex to the other one .",
    "choose one of the two vertices of @xmath50 to be the basepoint @xmath51 , and define the rose @xmath52 to be the result of wedging together @xmath4 copies of @xmath50 at the basepoint .",
    "the petals of the rose @xmath52 can be identified with the generators @xmath53 of @xmath1 , so that @xmath54 .",
    "there is an action of @xmath55 on @xmath52 given by inverting each petal of the rose .",
    "this action realizes the subgroup @xmath56 in the sense of @xmath57}$ ] ( also cf .",
    "@xcite . ) an action of a group @xmath41 on a graph @xmath58 is _ without inversions _ if @xmath41 does not send any edge @xmath59 to its inverse @xmath60 , and an action is _ reduced _ if there are no @xmath41-invariant subforests in @xmath58 .",
    "the action of @xmath61 on @xmath52 is both without inversions and reduced .",
    "from now on , when we refer to a group action on a graph , it is assumed that the edges of the graph are subdivided as necessary to insure that the group acts without inversions .",
    "note that the palindromic automorphism group @xmath0 is just @xmath62 .",
    "this follows because an easy argument shows that every element of @xmath62 is palindromic , and because the generators of @xmath0 are all in @xmath62 .",
    "for example , the generators @xmath11 are just products of @xmath61-nielsen transformations ( see @xcite where the @xmath41-nielsen transformation @xmath63 of a @xmath41-graph @xmath58 has the same vertex and edge set as @xmath58 but where the terminal point of an edge @xmath64 , @xmath65 , in the new graph is the initial point of the edge @xmath66 in the original graph ; this induces a map @xmath67 from the fundamental groupoid of the first graph to that of the second where @xmath64 is sent to @xmath68 and all other edges are sent to themselves . )",
    "that is , if the petal @xmath53 of the rose consists of the edges @xmath69 , then @xmath11 is the composition @xmath70 .    as a note for the curious",
    ", it follows that @xmath0 and @xmath30 are distinct groups for @xmath71 , since a direct argument shows that @xmath30 has no element of order 2 in its center .",
    "in addition , @xmath19 and @xmath24 are also obviously distinct ( for @xmath72 ; for @xmath73 they are the same group with the same presentation , ) since the former abelianizes to an elementary abelian @xmath74-group of rank @xmath75 while the latter abelianizes to a free abelian group of rank @xmath75 .",
    "in addition to its formal palindromic properties , the group @xmath0 arises naturally from looking at hyperelliptic subgroups of mapping class groups ( cf .",
    "gries @xcite for corresponding homological properties . )",
    "we have a commutative diagram @xmath76 where @xmath77 is the mapping class group of an orientable surface of genus @xmath78 , @xmath79 is the mapping class group of an orientable surface of genus @xmath78 with 1 puncture , and @xmath80 is the mapping class group of an orientable surface of genus @xmath78 with two punctures , where each puncture is fixed pointwise . the map from @xmath80 to @xmath81",
    "is obtained first by taking an intersection basis @xmath82 for the fundamental group of the surface @xmath83 with two punctures .",
    "one of the punctures should serve as the basepoint for fundamental group considerations .",
    "the other is treated as an actual puncture , so that the fundamental group of the surface minus this point is a free group @xmath84 on @xmath85 generators .",
    "the map from @xmath80 to @xmath81 is now obtained by sending an element of @xmath80 to the automorphism of @xmath84 that it induces .",
    "the map from @xmath79 to @xmath86 is obtained similarly .",
    "let @xmath87 be a hyperelliptic involution ( see , for example , @xcite . )",
    "then @xmath88 has @xmath89 fixed points , two of which are of course the punctures on the surface @xmath83 .",
    "choose loops @xmath82 , based at one of the punctures , which form an intersection basis for the surface @xmath83 ( say the ones described in @xcite in the section on hyperelliptic riemann surfaces . ) by going along the top row of diagram [ c24 ] and then projecting downward , we see that the image of @xmath88 in @xmath90 is @xmath91 .",
    "let @xmath92 be the image of @xmath88 in @xmath81 .",
    "our goal is to show that @xmath92 is conjugate to @xmath93 in @xmath81 .",

    "this follows directly since @xmath91 is in the center of @xmath96 .",

    "we define a certain contractible space @xmath43 , related to auter space , which @xmath0 acts on with finite stabilizers and finite quotient .",
    "this allows us to obtain some cohomological results .",
    "a graph @xmath58 is a _",
    "@xmath50-tree of rank @xmath4 _ if there exists a pointed tree @xmath149 such that @xmath58 is obtained by `` doubling '' every edge of @xmath149 into a @xmath50-graph .",
    "that is , the vertex set of @xmath58 is the same as the vertex set of @xmath149 and for every edge @xmath59 of @xmath149 going from @xmath111 to @xmath150 , @xmath58 has two edges @xmath151 and @xmath152 , both of which go from @xmath111 to @xmath150 .",
    "there is a natural @xmath153-action on such a graph @xmath58 , which is given by switching the two edges in each @xmath50-graph .",
    "note that the orbit space of @xmath58 under this action is just the tree @xmath149 .",
    "[ c1 ] the reduced graphs @xmath58 which realize the subgroup @xmath56 of @xmath3 are exactly the @xmath50-trees of rank @xmath4 , where @xmath61 acts on the trees via their natural @xmath153-action .    we have already mentioned that the rose @xmath52 realizes @xmath61 . from theorem 2 of @xcite , the other reduced graphs",
    "@xmath58 which also realize @xmath154 are those that are nielsen equivalent to @xmath52 ( up to an equivariant isomorphism . )",
    "if @xmath59 is an edge in one of the copies of @xmath50 in @xmath52 and @xmath129 is an edge in a different @xmath50 in @xmath52 , and both @xmath59 and @xmath129 point toward the basepoint , then nielsen transformation @xmath155 has the result of pulling the @xmath50-graph @xmath156 through the @xmath50-graph @xmath157 , so that now @xmath59 terminates at the initial vertex of @xmath129 , rather than at the basepoint @xmath51 . in other words , the result of applying one nielsen transformation to @xmath52",
    "is that of sliding one of the petals of @xmath52 up though another petal .",
    "a basic induction argument now yields that the result of applying a series of nielsen transformations fo @xmath52 will be some @xmath50-tree @xmath58 .",
    "recall from @xcite that an edge @xmath59 of a @xmath41-graph @xmath58 is _ inessential _ if it is in every maximal @xmath41-invariant subforest of @xmath58 .",
    "a @xmath41-graph @xmath58 is _ inessential _ if it has at least one inessential edge and is _ essential _ if it is not inessential .",
    "let @xmath158 be the fixed point subspace of @xmath44 corresponding to some finite subgroup @xmath41 of @xmath3 . from @xcite ( cf .",
    "part iii of @xcite and @xcite ) , both the centralizer @xmath159 and the normalizer @xmath160 act on the contractible space @xmath158 with finite stabilizers and finite quotient .",
    "moreover , the space @xmath158 @xmath41-equivariantly deformation retracts to the space @xmath161 , where @xmath161 is constructed from @xmath158 by considering only essential marked graphs .",
    "hence @xmath161 is a good space to study if one wishes to calculate the cohomology of @xmath159 or @xmath160 .",
    "further recall that a @xmath41-graph @xmath162 is a @xmath41-equivariant _ blowup _ of a @xmath41-graph @xmath58 if some @xmath41-invariant subforest @xmath163 of @xmath162 can be collapsed away to yield @xmath58 .",
    "let @xmath164 be some reduced marked graph realizing @xmath56 . from claim [ c1 ]",
    ", @xmath58 is a @xmath50-tree .",
    "blow up @xmath58 @xmath61-equivariantly to some maximal essential blowup @xmath162 .",
    "[ c2 ] the fixed points / cells of the action of @xmath61 on @xmath162 are exactly the valence 2 vertices of @xmath162 .    note that vertices in @xmath162 have valence 2 or 3 and that @xmath162 is obtained from @xmath58 by blowing up an oriented ideal forest ( see @xcite , @xcite , @xcite . )",
    "briefly , ideal edges ( oriented ideal forests ) correspond to subsets of edges ( chains of subsets of edges ) which are pulled away from existing vertices in order to create new graphs which collapse down to the original graph . )",
    "no edge is in @xmath165 because no edge is in @xmath166 and so blowing up ideal edges will not create any new edges that are fixed under the action of @xmath61 ( see @xcite page 229 . )    if a valence 3 vertex is in @xmath165 , then at least one edge of @xmath162 must be fixed by @xmath61 , which is a contradiction .",
    "all of the valence 2 vertices of @xmath58 are in @xmath166 .",
    "new valence 2 vertices created as ideal edges are blown up correspond to either :    * old vertices of @xmath58 that used to be valence higher than 2 but have since had edges stripped ( pulled away ) from them .",
    "these are in @xmath165 because all vertices of @xmath58 are in @xmath166 .",
    "* new valence 2 vertices inserted to insure that @xmath61 acts on @xmath162 without inversions .",
    "these are also clearly in @xmath165 .",
    "note that @xmath167 .",
    "cut @xmath162 along each of its valence 2 vertices , yielding a graph @xmath168 with the same number of valence 3 vertices and edges as @xmath162 had , no valence 2 vertices , and twice as many valence 1 vertices as @xmath162 had valence 2 vertices .",
    "[ c3 ] @xmath169 the disjoint union of two trees @xmath170 and @xmath171 , where @xmath172 .",
    "there is a covering map @xmath173 obtained by mapping to the orbit space under the @xmath61-action .",
    "the forest collapse that sends @xmath162 to @xmath58 is @xmath61-equivariant , so it descends to a forest collapse of @xmath174 to @xmath175 .",
    "( that the quotient of the forest upstairs in @xmath162 is also a forest in @xmath174 can be seen by an easy euler characteristic argument . ) but @xmath58 is a @xmath50-tree with a known @xmath61-action on it , and @xmath175 is a tree ( in fact , the underlying tree of the @xmath50-tree . ) hence @xmath174 is a tree .",
    "since @xmath173 is a covering map with fiber two points , @xmath168 is as described .",
    "let @xmath149 be a pointed tree with @xmath176 edges , all vertices valence either 1 or 3 , where @xmath51 is one of the valence 1 vertices .",
    "( then @xmath149 has @xmath177 valence 1 vertices and @xmath31 valence 3 vertices . )",

    "define @xmath181 define a @xmath61-action on @xmath182 by @xmath183    [ c4 ] there is a bijective correspondence between trees @xmath149 as above ( with @xmath176 edges , etc ) and maximal , essential blowups @xmath162 of reduced @xmath61-graphs .",
    "the bijection is given by @xmath184 .    from claims [ c2 ] and [ c3 ] , all blowups",
    "@xmath162 have the required form .",
    "finally , any @xmath182 can easily be reduced to a @xmath50-tree by collapsing edges , meaning that it is the blowup of such a graph .",
    "all maximal simplices in @xmath43 have the same dimension , from @xcite .",
    "maximal simplices in @xmath185 are constructed by taking chains of forest collapses from maximal blowups @xmath182 .",
    "alternatively , we can define a _ subforest _ of @xmath149 to be a collection @xmath83 of edges of @xmath149 such that there is no path in @xmath83 from one valence 1 vertex to another .",
    "( if there were such a path , then @xmath186 would be a cycle in @xmath182 . ) in this way , we can think of maximal simplices as coming from chains of subforests of various trees @xmath149 .    since @xmath0 acts on the contractible space @xmath43 with finite stabilizers and finite quotient , the vcd of @xmath0 is at most the dimension of a maximal cell from @xmath185 .",
    "such a cell comes from a chain of forest collapses of a tree @xmath149 with @xmath176 edges , @xmath177 valence 1 vertices , and @xmath31 valence 3 vertices .",
    "hence we can collapse at most @xmath31 of the valence 3 vertices into other vertices while doing forest collapses , resulting in maximal simplices of dimension @xmath31 .    to show that the vcd of @xmath0 is at least @xmath31",
    ", we note that the subgroup generated by @xmath187 for @xmath188 is isomorphic to @xmath189 .",
    "[ c6 ] let @xmath190 be the underlying graph of a particular marked graph in @xmath43 .",
    "hence @xmath190 comes equipped with a @xmath61-action .",
    "let @xmath191 be a simple closed curve in @xmath190 .",
    "then @xmath192 contains exactly two points , and @xmath193 is the curve @xmath194 , or @xmath191 with the opposite of its original orientation .",
    "@xmath190 can be blown up ( not necessarily uniquely ) to some maximal essential graph @xmath195 .",
    "@xmath58 is the union of two isomorphic copies @xmath178 and @xmath179 of @xmath149 , where @xmath178 and @xmath179 are attached along their corresponding valence 1 vertices .    as we collapse from @xmath58 to @xmath190 , the trees @xmath178 and @xmath179 collapse to trees @xmath196 and @xmath197 .",
    "however , the attaching points for @xmath196 and @xmath197 are no longer necessarily just the valence 1 vertices , and could be other vertices as well .",
    "let @xmath198 be a taut path in @xmath196 from one attaching point @xmath199 to some other attaching point @xmath200 , where furthermore there are no attaching points in the interior of @xmath198 .",
    "let @xmath201 be the corresponding path in @xmath197 .",
    "then @xmath202 is a simple closed curve and @xmath203 ) = @xmath204 , or the original curve oriented in the other direction .",
    "hence the curve @xmath202 satisfies the conclusions of the lemma .",
    "our goal is to show that any simple closed curve @xmath191 takes this form .",
    "let @xmath205 be the portion of @xmath191 that is in @xmath196 and let @xmath206 be the portion of @xmath191 that is in @xmath197 .",
    "since @xmath191 is a cycle and yet both @xmath196 and @xmath197 are trees , both @xmath205 and @xmath206 are nonempty . in fact , there must be a path @xmath198 in @xmath205 from one attaching point @xmath199 to some other attaching point @xmath200 , where there are no other attaching points in the interior of the path .",
    "since @xmath191 is a simple closed curve , @xmath198 must be a taut path .",
    "let @xmath207 , some other taut path in @xmath190 from @xmath199 to @xmath200 .",
    "let @xmath208 be the map given by taking the quotient space under the action of @xmath61 .",
    "note that @xmath209 is a path from @xmath199 to @xmath200 .",
    "since @xmath196 is a tree and @xmath198 is the unique taut path in @xmath196 from @xmath199 to @xmath200 , this gives us that @xmath210 .",
    "hence if @xmath59 is an edge in @xmath198 , then @xmath211 is two edges , @xmath212 and @xmath213 .",
    "it follows that all of the oriented edges of the simple closed curve @xmath214 are in the simple closed curve @xmath191 .",
    "hence @xmath215    [ c7 ] let @xmath190 be the underlying graph of a particular marked graph in @xmath43 . hence @xmath190 comes equipped with a @xmath61-action .",
    "choose an edge @xmath59 in @xmath190 .",
    "among all simple closed curves @xmath216 which pass through @xmath59 , choose one curve @xmath191 for which the distance from the curve to the basepoint @xmath51 is minimal .",
    "then @xmath192 is two points @xmath199 and @xmath200 .",
    "one of these two points in the closest point in @xmath191 to the basepoint @xmath51 and one of them is the farthest point in @xmath191 to the basepoint @xmath51 .    using the notation of the proof of lemma [ c6 ]",
    ", @xmath191 is the result of following some path @xmath198 in @xmath196 and then @xmath217 in @xmath197 , where @xmath198 goes from the attaching point @xmath199 to the attaching point @xmath200 .",
    "since @xmath198 is a path in a pointed tree , there is a unique vertex @xmath150 in @xmath198 which is closest to @xmath51 . by way of contradiction , suppose that @xmath218 .",
    "then @xmath150 is not an attaching point .",
    "let @xmath219 be the unique taut path in @xmath196 from @xmath51 to @xmath150 .",
    "let @xmath220 be the unique subpath of @xmath219 which contains @xmath150 and exactly one attaching point @xmath221 .",
    "now let @xmath222 be the path in @xmath196 which starts at @xmath221 , follows @xmath220 along to @xmath150 , and then either follows @xmath191 from @xmath150 to @xmath200 or @xmath194 from @xmath150 to @xmath199 ( where we choose whichever possibility insures that @xmath223 . )",
    "then the simple closed curve @xmath224 is closer to @xmath51 than @xmath191 is , which is a contradiction .",
    "hence @xmath150 is @xmath199 or @xmath200 , and the lemma follows .",
    "[ c8 ] let @xmath190 be a graph which occurs as an underlying graph of marked graphs in @xmath43 .",
    "then there is only one possible @xmath61-action on @xmath190 .",
    "we see that our task is to show that a unique @xmath61-action is determined by the properties about simple closed curves listed in lemmas [ c6 ] and [ c7 ] .",
    "define an action @xmath225 on @xmath190 as follows .",
    "let @xmath59 be an oriented edge of @xmath190 . among all simple closed curves @xmath216 which pass through @xmath59 , choose one path @xmath191 for which the distance from the curve to the basepoint @xmath51 is minimal .",
    "let @xmath199 be a point on @xmath191 which is closest to the basepoint .",
    "let @xmath4 be the edge - path distance in @xmath191 from @xmath199 to @xmath59 .",
    "then there is an orientation @xmath226 such that if you traverse @xmath227 starting at @xmath199 and go @xmath4 edges , you get to @xmath59 . define @xmath228 to be the result of traversing @xmath229 starting at @xmath199 and then going @xmath4 more edges .    by lemma [ c6 ] and [ c7 ] , the action @xmath225 is well defined and if any @xmath61 acts on @xmath190 , then the @xmath61-action and the @xmath225-action coincide .",
    "denote by @xmath230 the quotient space @xmath185 .",
    "[ c9 ] if two marked graphs in @xmath43 have the same underlying graph , then they correspond to the same vertex in @xmath230 .",
    "that is , the moduli space @xmath230 can be formed by looking only at the poset structure of the underlying graphs of marked graphs in @xmath43",
    ".    from proposition [ c8 ] , any underlying graph of a marked graph in @xmath43 has only one possible @xmath61-action .",
    "but from corollary 10.4 of @xcite , @xmath0 acts transitively on the set of marked @xmath61-graphs based on the same @xmath61-graph . the result follows .",
    "the simplices of @xmath43 group themselves into cubes , as described in  3 of @xcite . in @xcite , hatcher and vogtmann show that the quotients in @xmath231 of cubes in @xmath44 have the rational homology of balls .",
    "they use this to create a cubical chain complex which has the same rational homology as @xmath231 .",
    "our goal here is to establish a similar result for the cubes of maximal dimension in @xmath230 , where this time we want the quotients of cubes to have the @xmath232-cohomology of balls , where @xmath33 is any odd prime .",
    "following @xcite , we consider a maximal cube in @xmath43 .",
    "it is given by considering a maximal essential marked graph @xmath233 and considering some maximal subforest @xmath83 of @xmath149 .",
    "recall that by a subforest of @xmath149 we mean a subset @xmath83 of the edges of @xmath149 where there is no path in @xmath83 from one valence 1 vertex of @xmath149 ( or equivalently , one terminal edge of @xmath149 ) to another . from part",
    "a ) of theorem [ c34 ] , @xmath83 has @xmath31 edges in it .",
    "the cube corresponding to the pair @xmath234 can thus be thought of as imbedded in @xmath235 , where each coordinate vector is an edge of the cube , the graph obtained by collapsing each edge of @xmath236 is at the origin , and @xmath182 is at @xmath237 .",
    "let @xmath238 be the group of all ( pointed ) automorphisms of the tree @xmath149 which take @xmath83 to @xmath83 .",
    "the group @xmath239 acts linearly on the cube by permuting the coordinates of @xmath235 , and fixes the diagonal from @xmath240 to @xmath237 .",
    "( the involution @xmath61 acts trivially on the cube , of course , since all of these cubes are coming from @xmath241 . )",
    "hence , just as in @xcite , the quotient of the cube in @xmath230 is a cone with base @xmath242 , where @xmath243 is the boundary of the cube .",
    "[ c10 ] the finite group @xmath244 ( and hence its subgroup @xmath238 ) is all @xmath74-torsion .",
    "let @xmath245 .",
    "now @xmath246 must take the basepoint to the basepoint , and so it must take the unique edge attached to the basepoint to itself . for each @xmath4",
    ", let @xmath247 be the edges in @xmath149 which are at most distance @xmath4 from @xmath51 .",
    "so @xmath248 is just one edge , and @xmath246 fixes it as already mentioned .",
    "since all nonterminal vertices of @xmath149 have valence 3 , an inductive argument yields that @xmath249 fixes @xmath247 pointwise .",
    "the following is an analog of proposition 3.1 of @xcite :    [ c11 ] @xmath242 has the @xmath232-cohomology of an @xmath250-sphere or a ball .",
    "the latter possibility happens when there is an element of @xmath238 which induces an odd permutation of the edges of @xmath83 .",
    "the finite group @xmath238 , which is all 2-torsion , acts cellularly on @xmath243 , where the stabilizer of a cell fixes it pointwise .",
    "we use the spectral sequence for equivariant cohomology ( cf .",
    "@xcite vii  7 ) : @xmath251 \\in \\delta_n^r } h^s(stab(\\delta ) ; { \\mathbb{z}}_{(p ) } ) \\rightarrow h_{aut(t , s)}^{r+s}(s^{n-2 } ; { \\mathbb{z}}_{(p)})\\ ] ] where @xmath252 $ ] ranges over the set @xmath253 of orbits of @xmath254-simplices @xmath255 in @xmath243 . since @xmath238 is all @xmath74-torsion and finite ,",

    "the last assertion in the proposition follows from corollary 3.2 of @xcite .",
    "[ c14 ] the top dimensional cohomology group of @xmath230 vanishes .",
    "that is , @xmath268 .",
    "we show that the quotient of every maximal cube @xmath234 has a free face , so that the interior of the quotient of the cube can be collapsed away .",
    "if we can do this , then @xmath230 will have the same @xmath232-cohomology as an @xmath250-dimensional complex , and we will be done .    in the degenerate case where there is an element of @xmath238 which induces an odd permutation of the edges of @xmath83 , then the quotient of the cube @xmath234 is not itself a cube . in this case",
    ", the diagonal from @xmath269 to @xmath270 is exposed in the quotient , and any @xmath250-dimensional simplex in the quotient which lies next to the diagonal is a free face .    in the nondegenerate case ,",
    "the quotient of the cube @xmath234 is itself a cube , although its boundary might be self indentified in various ways .",
    "since the subforest @xmath83 of @xmath149 is maximal , @xmath83 must contain at least one terminal edge @xmath59 .",
    "that is , one of the two vertices of @xmath59 is a valence 1 vertex or attaching point .",
    "let @xmath190 be the graph obtained from @xmath195 by collapsing the subforest @xmath271 .",
    "the graph @xmath190 has a maximal subforest corresponding to collapsing the edges @xmath59 and @xmath272 from the forest @xmath236 of @xmath58 .",
    "hence we see that collapsing @xmath59 gives us a face , which we will denote by @xmath273 , of the cube @xmath234 .",
    "it can be shown that this face corresponds to a ( nondegenerate , cubical ) face of the quotient of the cube @xmath234 because    [ c15 ] there is an natural injection of @xmath274 into @xmath275 .",
    "define the lift @xmath276 of an automorphism @xmath277 by sending an edge @xmath129 to @xmath278 if @xmath279 and letting @xmath280 .",
    "denote by @xmath111 the valence 1 vertex of @xmath281 ( the attaching point ) and let @xmath150 be the other vertex of @xmath59 . in @xmath282 , @xmath283 .",
    "we must show that @xmath95 sends @xmath150 to @xmath150 .",
    "this follows automatically , however , as @xmath284 is the only valence 4 vertex of @xmath190 and so any automorphism of the graph must fix it .",
    "let @xmath129 and @xmath78 be the two other edges in @xmath149 which share the vertex @xmath150 .",
    "now if @xmath285 then @xmath95 could possibly exchange @xmath129 and @xmath78 , but this is fine as the lift @xmath276 also can .",
    "if @xmath109 , then one of @xmath129 or @xmath78 must be closer to the basepoint , and so @xmath95 must fix both @xmath129 and @xmath78 .",
    "regardless , @xmath276 can be defined as in the statement of the claim .",
    "warning : note that if @xmath59 is not a terminal edge , the above claim is false .",
    "collapsing an interior edge somtimes allows you to construct automorphisms with 3-torsion , which obviously can not be lifted to @xmath244 .",
    "no automorphism @xmath95 of @xmath273 can induce an odd permutation of the edges in @xmath286 , else the lift @xmath276 of @xmath95 to @xmath149 would induce an odd permutation of the edge of @xmath83 .",
    "since @xmath244 is all 2-torsion , it follows from the above claim that @xmath287 is also all 2-torsion . hence the same spectral sequence argument used in proposition [ c11 ] yields that the quotient of the cube corresponding to @xmath273 actually is a @xmath232-cohomology cube .",
    "it remains to be shown that the cubical face corresponding to @xmath273 is free .",
    "first , if another subforest @xmath288 with an edge @xmath289 of @xmath149 gives a cube with a face isomorphic to @xmath290 , then @xmath289 must also be a terminal edge of @xmath288 .",
    "hence the isomorphism @xmath291 maps the vertex that @xmath59 collapsed into to the the vertex that @xmath289 collapsed into , and so we can lift the isomorphism to one from @xmath292 .",
    "second , we must show that blowing up the vertex @xmath150 in @xmath190 only yields graphs isomorphic to @xmath58 .",
    "this follows by considering the ways that the vertex @xmath150 in @xmath190 can be blown up .",
    "say that the edges @xmath129 , @xmath78 , @xmath293 , and @xmath294 are the ones incident to @xmath150 . if the ideal edge orbit @xmath295 is blown up , we get back @xmath58 exactly , and if @xmath296 is blown up , we get a graph isomorphic to @xmath58 . as these are the only ways to blow up the graph @xmath61-equivariantly into another essential graph , we are done .",
    "[ c16 ] @xmath297 .",
    "that @xmath298 follows immediately from theorem [ c14 ] .",

    "let @xmath33 be an odd prime ( as will always be the case from now on in this paper . )",

    "we show that @xmath392 is the only conjugacy class of nontrivial elementary abelian @xmath33-subgroups that is in @xmath0 . by proposition [ c18 ]",
    ", we see that an arbitrary nontrivial elementary abelian @xmath33-subgroup @xmath320 comes from some action on a @xmath50-tree with @xmath33-symmetry .",
    "since @xmath395 , the only possibility is that @xmath320 acts on a @xmath50-tree @xmath58 by rotating @xmath33 of the @xmath50-leaves and leaving the other @xmath393 @xmath50-edges in the tree fixed .",
    "but it is clear that a product of @xmath397-nielsen transformations takes the rose @xmath52 to the graph @xmath58 , and hence we see that @xmath320 and @xmath392 are conjugate to each other in @xmath0 .",

    "define a _ @xmath33-admissible tree _",
    "@xmath149 to be a triple @xmath465 where @xmath149 is a pointed tree , @xmath466 is a vertex of @xmath149 ( which may be the basepoint @xmath51 ) , @xmath320 is a subset of the vertices of @xmath149 called the _ set of attaching points _ , @xmath467 , and all valence 1 vertices of @xmath149 are in @xmath320 . for a @xmath33-admissible tree @xmath149 ,",
    "define the _ corresponding graph _ @xmath182 as follows : take two isomorphic copies @xmath178 and @xmath179 of the tree @xmath149 , and let @xmath180 be an isomorphism .",
    "then let @xmath468 be the graph @xmath469 let @xmath470 be a @xmath47-graph with @xmath33 edges and two vertices @xmath199 and @xmath200 .",
    "let @xmath471 be the @xmath466-vertex in @xmath178 and let @xmath472 be the @xmath466-vertex in @xmath179 .",
    "finally , let @xmath473 if @xmath474 , then say @xmath149 is a @xmath33-admissible tree of _ rank _ @xmath4 .    if @xmath149 is a @xmath33-admissible tree of rank @xmath4 , define a @xmath56-action on the edges of @xmath182 by @xmath475 since this action inverts the edges of the @xmath47-graph in @xmath182 , we then need to subdivide these edges so that the group acts without inversions .",
    "next , define a @xmath392-action on @xmath182 by having @xmath392 fix @xmath468 and rotate the edges of @xmath470 cyclically . in this way , @xmath182 is a @xmath397-graph .    a @xmath33-admissible tree is @xmath149 _ reduced _ if the corresponding @xmath397-graph @xmath182 is reduced ; that is , if all vertices of @xmath149 are attaching points .",
    "similarly , a @xmath33-admissible tree @xmath149 is a _",
    "maximal _ if the attaching points of @xmath149 are exactly its valence 1 vertices , the valence @xmath74 vertices of @xmath149 consist of just the point @xmath466 , and @xmath149 has no vertices with valence 4 or more .",
    "as before , a _ subforest",
    "_ of @xmath149 is a collection of edges @xmath83 of @xmath149 such that there is no path in @xmath83 from one attaching point to another .",
    "lastly , isomorphisms of @xmath33-admissible trees must be graph isomorphisms which take @xmath51 to @xmath51 , @xmath466 to @xmath466 , and @xmath320 to @xmath320 .        1 .",
    "there is a bijective correspondence between reduced @xmath33- admissible trees of rank @xmath4 and the underlying graphs of @xmath397- reduced marked graphs , given by @xmath476 .",
    "2 .   there is a bijective correspondence between maximal @xmath33-admissible trees of rank @xmath4 and the underlying graphs of maximal essential marked @xmath397-graphs , given by @xmath476 .",
    "the virtual cohomological dimension of @xmath462 is @xmath477 .",
    "4 .   let @xmath58 be a graph which occurs as the underlying graph of a marked graph in @xmath463 .",
    "then there is only one possible @xmath61-action on @xmath58 .",
    "if two marked graphs in @xmath463 have underlying graphs which correspond to the same @xmath33-admissible tree , then they correspond to the same vertex in @xmath478 .",
    "that is , we can form the moduli space @xmath478 by looking only at the poset structure of the @xmath33-admissible trees corresponding to marked graphs in @xmath463 .",
    "the top dimensional cohomology class of @xmath478 , with coefficients in @xmath232 , vanishes .",
    "that is , @xmath479 .",
    "@xmath480 .    note that ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) above are a little bit different from their analogs proposition [ c8 ] and corollary [ c9 ] .",
    "basically , the underlying graphs @xmath58 always have just one possible @xmath61-action , as before , but it is conceivable ( for example , if the graph contains two or more copies of @xmath470 inside it and we must decide which one @xmath392 rotates ) that it might have several possible @xmath392-actions . that is why we talk about @xmath33-admissible trees instead in ( 5 ) , since the vertex @xmath466 in the tree determines where the @xmath33 edges that @xmath392 rotates are located .",
    "we use the equivariant cohomology spectral sequence for @xmath462 acting on the contractible space @xmath463 with finite stabilizers and finite quotient @xmath478 .",
    "the equivariant cohomology spectral sequence for this action is @xmath482 \\in \\delta_{n}^r } \\hat h^s(stab_{n_{aut(f_n)}(p_n \\times \\langle\\sigma_n\\rangle)}(\\delta ) ;   { \\mathbb{z}}_{(p ) } ) \\hfill \\cr \\hfill \\rightarrow   \\hat h^{r+s}(n_{aut(f_n)}(p_n \\times \\langle\\sigma_n\\rangle ) ) ; { \\mathbb{z}}_{(p ) } ) \\cr}\\ ] ] where @xmath252 $ ] ranges over the set @xmath483 of orbits of @xmath254-simplices @xmath255 in @xmath463 .    from the decomposition",
    "@xmath484 we see that @xmath485 has @xmath33-rank 0 .",
    "since @xmath406 acts trivially on marked graphs in @xmath463 by permuting the edges of the @xmath47-graph attached at @xmath466 , it follows that for every simplex @xmath255 we have @xmath486    the @xmath487-page of the spectral sequence is @xmath267 in the rows where @xmath488 and a copy of the cellular cochain complex with @xmath368-coefficients of the @xmath489-dimensional complex @xmath478 in rows @xmath490 .",
    "it follows that the @xmath491-page has the form : @xmath492 hence we see that the spectral sequence converges at the @xmath491-page .",
    "* case 2 : * m=1 .",
    "then @xmath478 is a contractible 1-dimensional complex with 3 vertices and two edges .",
    "define the maximal @xmath33-admissible tree @xmath149 of rank @xmath4 to be the tree with three vertices @xmath51 , @xmath466 , @xmath111 and two edges @xmath151 , @xmath152 where @xmath151 goes from @xmath51 to @xmath466 and @xmath152 goes from @xmath466 to @xmath111 .",
    "the middle vertex of the 1-dimensional complex @xmath478 corresponds to the graph @xmath182 .",
    "the other two vertices and two edges @xmath478 correspond to the two possible ways that @xmath182 can be collapsed equivariantly .",
    "* case 3 : * m=2 .",
    "then @xmath478 is a 2-dimensional complex with 13 vertices , 28 edges , and 16 two - simplices .",
    "there are two maximal graphs in @xmath478 .",
    "simplices coming from the first graph are listed in figure [ hyper1 ] and simplices from the second graph are listed in figure [ hyper2 ] . in figures",
    "[ hyper1 ] and [ hyper2 ] , the maximal graphs are listed in the center .",
    "these maximal graphs can be collapsed in various ways , and these are listed around the periphery of the figures . in the graphs , a solid dot indicates the basepoint @xmath51 and the hollow dots represent attaching points @xmath466 for the @xmath47-graph @xmath470 . if there is only one hollow dot in a graph , both ends of the @xmath47-graph should be attached to that one vertex . upon identifying the boundaries of the simplices listed in figures [ hyper1 ] and [ hyper2 ]",
    ", we obtain the complex @xmath478 pictured in figure [ hyper3 ] .",
    "the complex is homeomorphic to the fletching of a dart , three half disks , all identified along a common line in their boundary .",
    "this complex is clearly contractible .",
    "d. j. collins , _ palindromic automorphisms of free groups _ , _ combinatorial and geometric group theory ( edinburgh , 1993 ) _ , london math .",
    "lecture note ser . , 204 , cambridge university press cambridge ( 1995 ) 63 - 72 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we examine the palindromic automorphism group @xmath0 of a free group @xmath1 , a group first defined by collins in @xcite which is related to hyperelliptic involutions of mapping class groups , congruence subgroups of @xmath2 , and symmetric automorphism groups of free groups . </S>",
    "<S> cohomological properties of the group are explored by looking at a contractible space on which @xmath0 acts properly with finite quotient . </S>",
    "<S> our results answer some conjectures of collins and provide a few striking results about the cohomology of @xmath0 , such as that its rational cohomology is zero at the vcd .    _ </S>",
    "<S> dedicated to peter hilton _ : + doc , note , i dissent . </S>",
    "<S> a fast never prevents a fatness . </S>",
    "<S> i diet on cod . </S>"
  ]
}
